description: From un- +â€Ž person. Coined by  George Orwell in 1949 as part of the Newspeak in his novel Nineteen Eighty-Four, where it refers to a person who has been executed or has fallen out of favor; whose entire history has been erased.

entries.meaning: A human who has been stripped of rights, identity or humanity.
examples: With his identity stolen, he became an unperson, unable to prove his existence to the government.

verbs.description: unperson (third-person singular simple present unpersons, present participle unpersoning, simple past and past participle unpersoned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To strip (a human being) of rights, identity or humanity.
